In recent years, researchers have focused on developing efficient and environmentally friendly technologies to obtain clean and renewable energy, making electrolysis of water an attractive research direction. The actual performance of water splitting largely depends on the efficiency of electrocatalysts, which can promote cathodic hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) or anodic oxygen evolution reaction (OER). Reducing metal nanostructures to the atomic level to construct single atom catalysts (SACs) has attracted great attention. Compared to traditional precious metal catalysts, single atom catalysts have better catalytic activity, lower cost, and higher stability. Among many single-atom catalyst materials, palladium (Pd) single-atom materials have significant advantages in the aspects of uniform active sites, unique coordination environment, adjustable electron cloud density, and optimized d-orbital electron distribution. This review first summarizes the single-atom structure characteristics, historical development and reaction mechanism of palladium catalyzed in HER and OER. Secondly, the synthesis methods and characterization characteristics of Pd SACs are introduced. Then, the modification strategies to improve the catalytic performance of HER and OER are summarized. Finally, the possible research direction of palladium atom catalyst in the field of electrolytic water is proposed. Graphical abstract This article first summarizes the development history, advanced characterization techniques, and commonly used synthesis methods of Pd-SAC. Secondly, it emphasizes the crucial role of palladium single-atom modification strategies in enhancing water splitting efficiency, specifically in HER and OER. Finally, a discussion is held on its future development. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Pd single atom catalysts Water splitting Modification strategies Hydrogen evolution reaction Oxygen evolution reaction Data availability The data that has been used is confidential. 1 Introduction With global population growth and economic development, fossil fuel consumption and carbon dioxide emissions have sharply increased [1]. Therefore, there is an urgent need to explore green energy to achieve the sustainable development goal of carbon neutrality. In recent years, researchers have been committed to developing efficient and environmentally friendly technologies to obtain clean and renewable energy [2–4]. In mainstream renewable energy systems, fuel cells, metal air cells, and water separators are considered effective methods for producing clean energy. A water separator is a device used to separate water from gaseous, liquid, or solid mixtures. It can be used to remove moisture from hydrogen gas during its preparation, thereby improving the purity of hydrogen gas, and so on [5]. It is an important chemical reaction that can generate renewable hydrogen fuel and can be used to drive applications such as fuel cells [6]. Electrochemical reactions often face problems such as slow reaction kinetics, poor stability, low selectivity, and high cost, which greatly limit the promotion and application of this technology in practical production [7,8]. Therefore, developing high-performance and low-cost electrocatalysts is of great significance for promoting the development of renewable energy storage and conversion technologies. Efficient and selective electrocatalysts play a crucial role in the conversion and storage of clean energy. SACs have developed rapidly, with atomic utilization rates approaching 100 % and unique catalytic activity, widely used in energy conversion and catalysis fields [9]. Among numerous single atom catalyst materials, Pd single atom materials exhibit significant advantages due to their high activity, good stability, low toxicity, and adjustability. Pd single atom catalyst is a catalyst in which a single palladium (Pd) atom is loaded in an isolated form on a carrier, and these individual Pd atoms act as active centers to play a role in catalytic reactions. From the perspective of the structural characteristics of Pd single atom catalysts, Pd atoms are highly dispersed in a single form on the surface or inside the carrier, isolated from each other, and there are no Pd bonds or nanoparticles formed by Pd atom aggregation, which maximizes the atomic utilization efficiency. By designing the carrier material, it is possible to achieve strong interactions between Pd atoms and the carrier. Stably bound together through chemical bonding or other forces such as coordination or electrostatic interactions. The isolated existence of a single Pd atom and its interaction with the carrier cause a change in its electronic structure. Compared with traditional Pd nanoparticles or bulk Pd materials, they have unique electronic properties, such as electron cloud density distribution and oxidation states, which affect their catalytic performance. The number of coordinating atoms around a single atom Pd is relatively small, and it is in a low coordination state with more surface dangling bonds. This low coordination environment makes Pd atoms highly active and selective, enabling more effective adsorption and activation of reactant molecules [10–12]. In the field of electrocatalytic water, Pd monoatomic catalyst has many advantages [13]. Pd monoatomic catalyst showed high catalytic activity in electrocatalytic hydrogen production from water. Noble metal platinum (Pt) group elements are a kind of metal with the highest electrocatalytic activity for hydrogen production. As one of the Pt group elements, Pd monoatomic catalyst also has excellent catalytic performance. It is found that Pd monoatomic catalyst can reduce the loading of precious metals, improve the atomic utilization of precious metals, and maintain high catalytic activity while reducing the cost. Compared with non-noble metal single-atom catalysts, Pd SACs can more effectively promote the electro catalytic hydrogen production from water under the same conditions [14]. Pd monoatomic catalyst can produce specific products with high selectivity in some cases. For example, under specific reaction conditions, hydrogen can be preferentially promoted and other by-products can be reduced [15,16]. In contrast, some non-noble metal or other metal single-atom catalysts may have poor selectivity, resulting in the formation of a variety of different products, reducing the efficiency and purity of the reaction [17]. Pd monoatomic catalysts usually have good stability. Because Pd atoms are dispersed on a specific support in the form of single atoms, there is a strong interaction between Pd atoms and the support, which helps to improve the stability of the catalyst [18]. In some studies, Pd SACs can maintain the stability of their structure and performance in the long-term electrocatalytic reaction process, while some non-noble metal or other metal single-atom catalysts may be prone to structural changes or deactivation in the reaction process [19]. Therefore, the Pd monoatomic catalyst used in the field of electrolytic water has the value of further research and improvement. However, Pd is an expensive precious metal, and its cost and scalability in large-scale applications pose a challenge. Reducing the cost of Pd SACs and developing more scalable preparation methods are key issues in developing practical applications [20]. In the early days of water electrolysis, the main focus was on traditional block metal catalysts and nanoparticle catalysts. After the concept of single atom catalysts was proposed, researchers began to attempt to use precious metals such as Pd to make single atom catalysts for water electrolysis, with research focusing on how to restrict Pd single atoms. With the advancement of material preparation technology and characterization methods, research on Pd single atom catalysts has gradually deepened, and attention has begun to be paid to the influence of the interaction between the carrier and Pd single atoms, the coordination environment of single atoms, and other factors on catalytic performance. Researchers have tried various types of supports, such as metal oxides, nitrides, etc., to optimize the performance of Pd single atom catalysts by changing the properties and structure of the supports. In recent years, with the increasing demand for efficient and low-cost catalysts for water electrolysis, research on Pd single atom catalysts has entered a period of rapid development. On the one hand, the preparation methods are constantly innovating, such as atomic layer deposition technology and wet chemical method, which are widely used in the preparation of Pd single atom catalysts, enabling more accurate single atom loading and structural control. On the other hand, interdisciplinary research is increasingly deepening, combining theoretical calculations, advanced in-situ characterization techniques, etc., to gain a deeper understanding of the reaction mechanism and activity origin of Pd single atom catalysts in the process of water electrolysis [21]. Fig. 1 lists some representative achievements in improving the catalytic activity of Pd single atoms. This review first summarizes the single-atom structure characteristics, historical development and reaction mechanism of palladium catalyzed in HER and OER. Secondly, the synthesis methods and characterization characteristics of palladium monoatomic catalyst are introduced. Then, the modification strategies to improve the catalytic performance of HER and OER are summarized. Finally, the possible research direction of Pd SAC in the field of electrolytic water is proposed. The synthesis methods, characterization and modification strategies of palladium monoatomic catalysts for water electrolysis are summarized in Fig. 2 . 2 The mechanism of water splitting 2.1 HER in acidic and alkaline media Hydrogen Evolution Reaction, as a cathodic reaction of electrolyzed water, can be further divided into three steps in its catalytic mechanism as shown in the following equation: (1) In acidic media Volmer reaction: H + + e − + H* → H* (2) Heyrovsky reaction: H* + H + + e − → H2 (3) Tafel reaction: H* + H* → H2 (4) In alkaline media Volmer reaction: H2O + e − → OH− + H* (5) Heyrovsky reaction: H* + H2O + e − → H2+ OH− (6) Tafel reaction: 2H2O + 2e− → 2OH− + H2 HER, as an important half reaction in electrochemical water splitting, undergoes 2e− reaction on the surface of the cathode electrode [22]. The Volmer reaction is the first step reaction shared by these two different media, where H +or H2O molecules in both media combine with electrons through a discharge process to form adsorbed hydrogen (Hads) on the electrode surface. In the subsequent process, the amount of Hads played a decisive role [23]. The process of reducing Hads to generate H2 generally follows one of two rules. The Tafel effect refers to the interaction between adsorbed hydrogen atoms when the value of Hads is at a high level, exhibiting a form of binding between them. But there is another situation called electrochemical desorption reaction or Herovsky reaction. That is to say, when Hads is low, Hads release H2 through secondary electron transfer with another H +or H2O molecule in acidic or alkaline media, respectively [24]. The main manifestations of HER on the catalyst surface are hydrogen adsorption and hydrogen desorption [25]. If you want to make the process of hydrogen desorption achievable, then according to the Sabatier principle. It is easy to conclude that catalysts need to exhibit just the right amount of hydrogen adsorption capacity during the reaction process. It can also be understood that the binding energy of M-Hads should not be too strong or too weak, in order to achieve effective hydrogen desorption [26]. The Gibbs free energy (ΔG H*) adsorption catalyst of hydrogen plays a unique and important role in the entire process. During the reaction, the magnitude of ΔG H* and the kinetic potential barrier of hydrolysis (ΔG H2O) determine the rate of the entire reaction [27]. Moreover, the geometry and electronic structure of SAC materials largely determine the specific values of ΔG H* and ΔG H2O. Therefore, the rational design of SAC materials is the core and key difficulty in improving HER catalytic efficiency [28]. 2.2 OER in acidic and alkaline media Oxygen Evolution Reaction, due to its slow kinetics, is often considered the main bottleneck of water splitting, which limits the efficiency of energy conversion [29]. Typically, OER intermediates are stable due to surface bound oxygen/peroxide species catalysts. The stability of intermediates and activation barriers is a key rate step in determining the total water oxidation rate. However, the intermediate properties of metal surfaces mainly depend on catalyst materials and reaction conditions (acidic and alkaline) [30]. This process involves continuous multi-step transfer of electrons and protons under corrosion potential, resulting in high overpotential, low energy efficiency, and limited lifespan. OER consists of four basic steps [31–33]. In acidic media, O2 molecules originate from H2O molecules, while in alkaline media, OH− is considered a precursor to O2. As shown in the following equation, the OER reaction is a direct four electron process: (7) In acidic media: H2O + * − e − → OH* + H + (8) OH* − e − → O* + H + (9) H2O + O* − e − → OOH*+ H + (10) OOH* − e − → O2 + H + (11) In alkaline media: OH− + * − e − → OH* (12) OH* + OH− − e − → O* + H2O (13) O* + OH− − e − → OOH* (14) OOH*+ OH− − e − → O2 + H2O Research has shown that the catalytic activity of OER can be predicted based on the adsorption free energy of active intermediates (ΔG OH*, ΔG O*, ΔG OOH*), and under alkaline conditions, the abundant OH− and lower oxygen evolution activation energy (ΔG OER) make it easy to catalyze OER [34]. Compared to alkaline OER, the challenges faced by acidic OER mainly come from: 1) Acidic conditions require more stable catalytic materials; 2) From a thermodynamics perspective, acidic conditions are not conducive to OH− adsorption, and the low concentration of surface OH− makes the oxidation process involving surface electrons more difficult. From a kinetics perspective, the activation energy is higher, which increases the difficulty of OER from both thermodynamic and kinetic aspects [35]. Compared to HER, OER involves more complex steps and produces various intermediates (including OH*, O*, and OOH* species) in acidic and alkaline media. Due to the complex multi-step reaction of OER, the overpotential of OER is higher. The complete hydrolysis of water can be carried out at room temperature (2H2O → 2H2 + O2). As shown in Fig. 3 , the positive and negative electrode materials are inserted into the aqueous solution. Connecting to the positive and negative poles of the power supply and apply a certain voltage to overcome the energy barrier required for the catalytic decomposition of water molecules. During this process, at 25 °C and 1 atm, the change in the free energy (ΔG) of water electrolysis at a theoretical voltage of 1.23 V is 237.2 kJ mol−1. However, the kinetic values of electrochemical reactions are not satisfactory. In order to reduce energy consumption and costs, it is necessary to select or design electrocatalysts with significant gain effects for electrochemical reactions to improve the efficiency of water splitting. 2.3 Mechanism of Pd catalyst for water electrolysis As the active center, Pd single atom has strong adsorption capacity for water molecules due to its unique electronic structure and low coordination environment. When water molecules are adsorbed on the surface of Pd atoms, they will interact with Pd atoms, which will distort and polarize the chemical bonds of water molecules to a certain extent [24]. Electron transfer occurs between Pd single atom and water molecule. The d electron of Pd atom can be fed back to the anti-bond orbit of water molecule, weakening the OH bond in water molecule, making water molecule more prone to dissociation, producing OH− and H +. In the process of HER, this is an important premise for the production of hydrogen. The dissociation generated H + will be adsorbed on the surface of Pd single atom, and Pd single atom can provide appropriate electrons to H +, so that the electrons obtained by H + are reduced to hydrogen atoms (H). The adjacent hydrogen atoms are further combined on the surface of Pd atoms to form hydrogen molecules (H2), which are then desorbed from the catalyst surface and enter the gas phase [36]. At the anode, the OH− generated by the dissociation of water molecules will be adsorbed to the surface of Pd single-atom. Pd single-atom can promote the oxidation reaction of OH− and make OH− lose electrons and generate hydroxyl radicals (OH*). A series of reactions will take place between multiple OH* to generate intermediate species such as OOH* and O*, which will further react and finally generate oxygen molecules (O2). In some cases, the interaction between Pd monatoms and the support will make the lattice oxygen in the support participate in the oxygen evolution reaction, and the lattice oxygen reacts with the adsorbed OH− or intermediate species to accelerate the OER process [37]. 3 Synthesis methods and characterization techniques 3.1 Method of synthesis 3.1.1 Atomic layer deposition Atomic Layer Deposition (ALD) refers to the deposition of metal atoms onto suitable carriers, such as carbon materials or metal oxides. For example, Ding et al. used glycine as a template and deposited Pd atoms on a carbon support to form highly active Pd SACs [38]. The atomic deposition method has the following advantages in preparing Pd SACs: ALD technology can deposit metals in the form of single atoms on the catalyst surface, thus achieving highly uniform single atom dispersion, avoiding the aggregation of metal clusters, and improving the stability and catalytic performance of the catalyst [39,40]. ALD technology can achieve precise control of metal deposition, adjust parameters such as deposition cycle number and deposition temperature, and thus achieve precise control of catalyst composition and structure [41]. ALD technology can deposit multiple layers of metals and various metal oxides, enabling the preparation of complex structures. For example, transition metal oxides can be deposited on the surface of Pd SACs to form PdO/TMO (TMO is a transition metal oxide) structures, thereby improving the catalytic performance of the catalyst. ALD technology can be used for the preparation of various substrates, including metals, oxides, semiconductors, etc., without being limited by the substrate material; This technology requires fewer precursors, is easy to store and transfer, and has a lower cost compared to other preparation methods [42]. Therefore, atomic layer deposition technology has advantages in preparing Pd SACs, such as good single atom dispersion, strong controllability, the ability to prepare various complex structures, suitability for multiple substrates, and low cost. The rapid development of electrocatalysts is not only due to the efficient catalytic center, but also depends on the construction and load of excellent conductive network carriers. Here, Xiang et al. [43] fabricated a 3D interwoven structure as shown in Fig. 4 a, in which Pd atoms were deposited on uniformly integrated MnO2 nanowires and carbon nanotubes (Pd/MnO2 CNTs). This method achieves a high degree of integration between the excellent catalytic performance of Pd and the outstanding conductivity of carbon nanotubes (CNTs). The SEM image shown in Fig. 4b clearly demonstrates the unique high entanglement of MnO2 nanowires and CNTs. The TEM analysis in Fig. 4c reveals two distinct material phases, namely crystalline MnO2 nanowires and bent CNTs. The use of this nanocomposite material can achieve superior dual-functional oxygen reduction (ORR/OER) reactions. By normalizing the recorded current density to the Pd loading of the catalyst to calculate the Pd mass activity (MAPd), it was found that the MAPd of Pd/ MnO2 CNT in Fig. 4d reached a value of 484 A g−1, which exceeded by more than fivefold the state-of-the-art Pd-based electronic catalysts (19–97 A g−1) and commercially available 20 wt% Pd/C (20 A g−1) operating in alkaline media. Therefore, the new nanomaterials loaded with Pd single atom materials prepared using this method exhibit extremely excellent cost-effectiveness and catalytic efficiency. 3.1.2 In-situ synthesis In situ synthesis is a method of directly generating the required materials in a reaction system. Specifically, it refers to the direct conversion of reactants into desired products in the reaction system during reforming reactions or other chemical reactions, without the need for further extraction, separation, purification, and other steps [44]. The main characteristic of in-situ synthesis method is that the reactants are present in the reaction system from beginning to end and continuously transform during the reaction until the desired product is formed. This method can greatly simplify the reaction process, reduce the operation of subsequent steps, and improve the yield and purity of the product [45,46]. Meanwhile, the in-situ synthesis method can also reduce the energy consumption of the reaction system, the loss of reactants, and environmental pollution. Common in-situ synthesis methods include reducing Pd ions to Pd atoms under catalytic reaction conditions, and directly forming Pd single atoms on the catalyst surface [47]. The advantages of in-situ synthesis method in synthesizing Pd single atom catalysts are as follows: it can achieve single atom dispersion, ensure high activity and selectivity of the catalyst, and thus improve the efficiency of catalytic reactions [48]. The in-situ synthesis method can achieve precise control of the particle size, dispersion, and structure of Pd SACs by adjusting the synthesis conditions and catalyst composition. Furthermore, it can fix Pd atoms on the carrier to prevent their aggregation and deactivation during the reaction, thereby improving the stability and recyclability of the catalyst [49,50]. The in-situ synthesis method is suitable for different carrier materials and catalytic reaction systems, with good scalability and adaptability, and can be applied to various catalytic reaction fields. In summary, the in-situ synthesis method has the advantages of high activity, high selectivity, strong controllability, good catalyst stability, scalability, and wide adaptability in the synthesis of Pd SACs. Luo et al. [51] reported a highly active MoS2 based catalyst achieving through chemical activation of its surface substrate. They achieved this by designing a thermodynamic spontaneous interface MoS2/Pd (II) redox reaction as shown in Fig. 4e. The doping of Pd atoms into the original Mo site leads to the generation of sulfur vacancies, which transforms 2H-MoS2 into a more stable 1 T-MoS2, achieving the stabilization of defect sites. In acidic solutions, the final Pd-MoS2 exhibits good HER performance on heteroatom doped MoS2 based materials, while also exhibiting good cycling stability and excellent leaching resistance beyond undoped MoS2 [47]. 3.1.3 Electrochemical deposition Cyclic voltammetry is an electrochemical technique used to study electrochemical reactions and measure electrochemical parameters. This method obtains electrochemical information by applying a series of potential pulses in the solution of the substance to be tested, and then measuring the current response [52]. Cyclic voltammetry can provide precise characterization of the electrochemical properties of catalysts, including the position, shape, and charge transfer process of redox peaks. This is crucial for understanding the electrochemical properties of Pd SACs [53]. Electrochemical deposition has high sensitivity and can detect very low concentrations of substances. For the synthesis of Pd SACs, this means that the peak current can be accurately measured in low concentration Pd solutions to determine the content of single atom catalysts. Electrochemical deposition can control the deposition amount and distribution of Pd single atoms by adjusting the electrode potential and the number of cyclic scans [54–56]. This is crucial for the synthesis of uniformly dispersed and highly stable Pd SACs. Electrochemical deposition can be used for real-time monitoring during catalytic reactions to understand the dynamic changes of catalysts. This is of great significance for studying the activity, stability, and reaction mechanism of catalysts [57]. Overall, electrochemical deposition has the advantages of high precision, high sensitivity, controllability, and real-time monitoring in the synthesis of Pd SACs, providing a useful tool and way for the research and development of high-performance Pd SACs. In recent research, electrochemical synthesis has emerged as a sustainable and atom-efficient strategy for the production of challenging chemical products [58,59]. By utilizing electrons as traceless redox agents, precise control over electrochemical synthesis can be attained by fine-tuning application parameters such as potential and electrolysis duration. Moreover, this eco-friendly electrochemical synthesis approach facilitates large-scale production of target products, relying solely on cost-effective potentiometers [60]. Although electrochemical synthesis technology has been widely explored in the preparation of organic molecules, its application in SACs production still needs further research. Lv et al. [61] developed a one-step electrochemical method, as illustrated in Fig. 5 a, to construct a zeolitic imidazolate frame-8 (ZIF-8) with assembled single metal atoms, providing a novel scalable strategy for the synthesis of SAC. The dispersed metal atoms in ZIF-8 (eZIF-M) aggregate through dynamic electrochemical processes. Notably, by simply altering the metal source, eZIF-M with different single metal atoms (M represents Pt, Au, Ir, Pd, Ru, Mo, Rh, and W) was obtained, demonstrating the catholicity of this method. 3.1.4 High temperature synthesis method The high-temperature synthesis method can uniformly diffuse Pd atoms onto the surface of the carrier at high temperatures, forming a single atom dispersed catalyst. This can improve the activity and selectivity of the catalyst [62]. The high temperature during the synthesis process can promote the formation of more stable bonds between the surface of the carrier and Pd atoms, reduce the aggregation and cluster formation of Pd atoms, and thus enhance the performance of single atom catalysts [63–65]. The high-temperature synthesis method is relatively simple, easy to operate, and does not require complex synthesis steps and conditions. The high-temperature synthesis method can control the diffusion degree of Pd atoms by adjusting the diffusion temperature and time, thereby achieving control over the particle size and dispersion of SACs, with high controllability [66]. The high-temperature synthesis method is suitable for different types of carrier materials, such as metal oxides, carbon materials, etc., expanding the application range of SACs. At high temperatures, Pd atoms are forcibly diffused into the carrier material to form Pd SACs [67]. As a typical member of transition metals, MoS2 has garnered widespread attention in the HER of disulfides. However, research has revealed that the exposed plane of two-dimensional MoS2 is inert to HER, while the edge sites exhibit greater activity. Liu et al. [68] proposed a Pd doping method to enhance the in-plane and structural activity of MoS2 monolayers, and conducted a detailed study on the relationship between the two. They prepared single-layer Pd-MoS2 thin films with Pd-S bonds using room temperature impregnation followed by high-temperature annealing at 500 °Celsius, as illustrated in Fig. 5b. As shown in Fig. 5c, in order to gain a deeper understanding of the electrochemical kinetics, their Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurements showed that the resistance (R ct) of the 7.4 % Pd-MoS2 comes out to be the lowest. In contrast, the R ct of single-layer pure molybdenum disulfide on the single-layered nano-thick F doped SnO2 (FTO) is much larger, indicating that Pd insertion into the basal surface of single-layer molybdenum disulfide will result in a faster charge transfer rate in HER [69]. As shown in Fig. 5d, by plotting the relationship between Δj and scanning rate at different scanning rates, the double-layer capacitance (C dl) was obtained, and the C dl value of 7.4 % Pd-MoS2 was much higher than that of other samples. For Pd-MoS2 samples, the enhancement in C dl value may be related to the increase in active sites caused by the increase in Pd doping amount. The isolated atoms loaded on the surface of a single a SACs maximize the utilization of metals in multiphase catalysis [70]. Gong et al. [71] reported a feasible pyrolysis strategy to synthesize palladium single atoms by hot melting palladium nanoparticles on a tungsten oxide matrix rich in oxygen vacancies in a reducing atmosphere. As shown in Fig. 5e, the WO3− x sample reduced by H2 exhibited very poor acidic HER activity, with an overpotential of up to 595 mV at 10 mA cm−2. However, for Pd deposited on the WO3− x carrier, a significant enhancement of HER activity was observed, indicating that the anchored Pd species were the main contributors to enhancing acidic HER activity. As shown in Fig. 5f, the Tafel slope of the H2 reduced Pd/WO3− x is the smallest (68 mV dec−1), indicating its high kinetic performance [72]. And under the same conditions, the H2 reduced Pd/WO3− x comes out to be better. Its work may involve the rational design of fantastic SACs and the elucidation of corresponding enhanced reaction mechanisms using advanced characterization techniques. 3.2 Characterization techniques 3.2.1 Electron microscopy technology A deep understanding of the electronic structure and local coordination environment of catalysts at the atomic level can effectively promote the understanding of structural property relationships, which will be beneficial for the preparation of more advanced water electrolysis electrocatalysts in the future [60,73,74]. However, the precise characterization and identification of the atomic structure and coordination environment of active sites in SACs still pose challenges, mainly due to the complex supporting structure and the amorphous ordering of individual metal atoms. Therefore, there is an urgent need for advanced characterization techniques with high spatial resolution [75]. In the past few years, the development of modern technology has made it possible to more accurately characterize single atom catalysts [76]. The rapid development of, Aberration-Corrected Scanning Transmission Electron Microscopy (AC-STEM) has enabled researchers to directly visualize the rich separation of metal atoms in SACs, and directly observe the image of individual metal atoms anchored on the carrier, making it an indispensable characterization tool in current single atom catalyst research [77]. Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) can provide information on the microstructure and morphology of catalysts, as well as the distribution and composition at the atomic scale [78]. Scanning Transmission Electron Microscopy (STEM) can obtain high-resolution atomic scale images and obtain element distribution information through Energy Disperse Spectroscopy (EDS) analysis [79]. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) can observe the surface morphology of the sample. As shown in Fig. 6 a, Chi et al. [80] provided a vertically arranged N-doped graphene nano-mesh array (VNGNMA) for synthesis. In order to observe the distribution morphology of Pd atoms, they used STEM technology to clearly observe that many individual Pd atoms (bright spots) in Fig. 6b were uniformly dispersed on the surface of VNGNMA. The Pd and Pt SACs loaded on 3D graphene nanowires outperform benchmark Pt/C and traditional SACs in hydrogen evolution reactions due to their fast mass transfer. By conducting linear sweep voltammetry measurements in 0.5 M H2SO4, the HER activity of Pd1 SACs-VNGNMA was measured and compared with the HER activity of commercial Pt/C catalysts. Fig. 6c clearly shows that the Pd1 SACs-VNGNMA catalyst exhibits excellent HER activity. 3.2.2 X-ray spectroscopy technology X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) can obtain information on the chemical state and composition of elements by measuring the photoelectron spectra on the surface of the sample [49]. Spectral technology has special advantages in characterizing single atom catalysts, such as high resolution, in situ research, multiple technical combinations, component analysis, and catalytic mechanism research. It helps to deeply understand the structure and performance of catalysts, and provides important basis for catalyst design and catalytic reaction optimization [81]. XPS is used to unpack the elemental composition of material surfaces, and can be used for semi quantitative analysis of elements, as well as for analyzing the chemical state of surface elements. Zheng et al. [82] observed the performance of Pd single atom supported catalysts and semi quantitatively analyzed the element content of different chemical states based on the XPS spectrum of O1 s in Fig. 6d-g. Changes in the doping amount of Pd mainly affect the surface O content. The surface oxygen content of 2 % Pd-SA/CeZrO2 (Pd-SA/CZ) accounts for 21.09 % of the three types of oxygen: surface oxygen, adsorbed oxygen, and planar oxygen. The highest surface oxygen content is observed among the four Pd doped catalysts with different contents shown in the figure. When Pd is loaded onto CZ, the presence of Pd causes lattice distortion, and as the lattice oxygen content decreases to a certain extent, excessive Pd will generate more lattice oxygen vacancies [41]. It is worth noting that only surface oxygen can effectively adsorb and activate O2, thereby promoting the progress of the reaction, that is, the amount of surface oxygen content determines the performance of the catalyst [83]. X-ray Absorption Fine Structure (XAFS) is the electromagnetic radiation generated by accelerating an electron beam to high velocity using an electron accelerator, which can provide high-resolution imaging and characterization [84,85]. This is very helpful for observing the atomic distribution and structure of Pd SACs, and can also be used for X-ray absorption spectroscopy analysis [57]. By analyzing the absorption of X-rays in the sample, information about the chemical environment and coordination of Pd SACs can be obtained, and so on [86]. 4 Modification strategies to promote catalytic activity of Pd single atom in HER In order to further improve the catalytic activity of Pd single atom in HER reaction, high dispersion is the key to high catalytic activity, ensuring that every atom can participate in HER reaction. Agglomeration will reduce the active sites and catalytic activity. The type, number and geometric arrangement of coordination atoms change the electronic structure and adsorption performance. Appropriate adsorption energy and stable intermediates are conducive to the reaction. The overall structure of the catalyst includes the relationship between Pd single atom, support, doped atom and alloy atom. Stable structure ensures long-term effectiveness, prevents loss and agglomeration, enhances anti poisoning ability and stability, maintains the integrity and activity of active sites, and continuously and efficiently catalyzes HER reaction. Therefore, following the electronic structure tuning and structure activity relationship of Pd SAC, in the continuous exploration, researchers proposed the following methods and ideas to improve the performance [87,88]. 4.1 Non-metallic atomic anchoring Non-metallic atom anchoring is a commonly used method for modifying Pd SACs, which includes the following aspects: by introducing non-metallic atoms, atomic vacancy points are formed on the Pd catalyst, allowing a single Pd atom to be stably fixed on the catalyst surface. These atomic hollow acupoints can form bonds with Pd atoms, limiting their formation of aggregated states. This anchoring effect can improve the stability of Pd atoms and prevent them from falling off the catalyst surface [89,90]. The introduction of non-metallic atoms can also regulate the morphology of catalysts, regulate surface pore structure, lattice distortion, etc., thereby improving the selectivity and activity of catalysts. The introduction of non-metallic atoms can also adjust the electron density of catalysts and thereby regulate their catalytic performance by altering the electronic interaction between Pd atoms and non-metallic atoms. When the non-metallic atoms (such as N, S, P, etc.) are used to anchor the Pd single atom, the density of the electron cloud of the Pd atom will be changed, and then the position of its d-band center will be adjusted. For example, nitrogen atom (N) has strong electronegativity. When it is coordinated with Pd single atom, it will attract the electrons of Pd atom and move down the d-band center of Pd. In HER reaction, the appropriate d-band center position can optimize the adsorption energy of hydrogen adsorbate. If the center of d-band is too high, it will lead to strong adsorption of hydrogen, which is not conducive to subsequent desorption of H2; If the center of d− band is too low and the adsorption of H is too weak, the reaction is difficult to proceed. By adjusting the center of d-band through non-metallic atom anchoring, the adsorption energy can be in a suitable range, so as to improve the catalytic activity of HER reaction. The introduction of nonmetallic atoms can create new electronic states around Pd single atoms. These new electronic states can be used as electron transfer channels to promote charge transfer in HER. In recent years, 2D materials have attracted widespread attention due to their high surface area, which may provide abundant active sites [91]. For example, graphite, graphene, g-C2 N, and g-C3N4 have been widely studied as electrocatalysts both theoretically and experimentally [92]. Li et al. [93] reported the successful synthesis of various precious metal (PM, PM=Pd, Pt, Rh, Ir, and Ru) single-atom catalysts on heteroatom-doping carbon (CN), labeled as SA-PM/CN, using a simple movable printing method as shown in Fig. 7 a. In short, the precursor of C3N4-PM is first prepared by the coordination ability between C3N4 and PM salts, and then these dispersed metal substances are shifted to nitrogen doped CN nanosheets derived from polydopamine through pyrolysis. Testing has found that a certain nitrogen content is beneficial for anchoring and stabilizing PM atoms. In addition, the TEM, EDS elemental maps shown in Fig. 7b, and high-angle annular dark field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) were used to determine that PM appeared as a single atom on the CN substrate. According to the results, single atom catalysts synthesized on CN exhibit better catalytic performance compared to nano-catalysts, as the unique structure of single atom catalysts results in higher atomic utilization efficiency [81]. The introduction of non-metallic atoms can change the geometry of adsorption sites around Pd single atoms. Chemical bonds are formed between non-metallic atoms, Pd atoms and supports, which enhance the stability of Pd atoms on supports. 4.2 Single atom alloying Single atom alloying is a commonly used modification method for Pd SACs [94]. The specific content is to form an alloy structure by combining Pd atoms with other metal atoms (usually transition metal atoms), so that Pd atoms exist as single atoms on the surface of the alloy. The specific steps of single atom alloying generally include the following aspects: according to the needs of catalytic reactions and the activity of catalysts, suitable metal atoms are selected as the components of alloying [95,96]. Commonly used metals include Pt, Cu, Ag, Au, Ni, Co, etc. Pre-treatment of Pd catalysts with metal atoms typically involves methods such as physical adsorption, chemical adsorption, and electrochemical deposition to introduce metal atoms onto the surface of Pd catalysts [7]. Put the pre-treated catalyst under high-temperature treat to form an alloy structure between Pd atoms and metal atoms. The specific conditions for alloying include temperature, atmosphere, time, etc. Different alloying conditions can affect the structure and catalytic performance of the catalyst [97]. Characterization and evaluation of Pd SACs prepared by alloying, including surface morphology, crystal structure, catalytic performance, etc. to determine whether the catalysts prepared by alloying have the expected performance [98]. The single atom alloying method has the following advantages: through the alloying method, a single Pd atom can be dispersed on the surface of another metal, forming a single atom alloy structure [99,100]. This structure has higher activity and selectivity compared to pure Pd catalysts. Alloying can enhance the interaction between catalysts and reactants, improve the rate and efficiency of reactions. Improve the stability of the catalyst. The single atom alloy structure can provide better stability and prevent the aggregation and aggregation of Pd atoms. This structure can reduce the metal surface area of Pd, reduce the energy of surface adsorption and catalytic reactions, thereby improving the stability and durability of the catalyst. When Pd atoms form single-atom alloys with other metal atoms, the electrons in the alloys will be redistributed among different metal atoms. The orbits of Pd single atom and alloy metal atom will be hybrid. The orbits of Pd single atom and alloy metal atom will be hybrid. The structure of single-atom alloys forms new active sites [101]. In HER reaction, the geometric structure and composition of these active sites determine the adsorption mode and reaction path of reactant molecules. Appropriate atomic spacing and arrangement can make protons more easily adsorbed on the active site, and is conducive to the subsequent reduction reaction, so as to improve the catalytic activity. Changes in the electronic structure of the active site (such as d-band center regulation and orbital hybridization) directly affect the kinetics of HER reaction. Appropriate electronic structure can reduce the energy barrier of the reaction and accelerate the process of proton adsorption, reduction and hydrogen desorption [102]. Single atom alloys (SAA) have a significant impact on electrocatalysis due to their unique structure. Due to strong metal interactions, the presence of single atom alloys combines the unique structure of SACs with the advantages of alloy catalysts in traditional research. It exhibits remarkable advantages in catalytic reactions. Numerous studies have found that Pd atoms dispersed on a carrier exhibit excellent catalytic activity [103]. For example, the reason why the presence of Pd-Pt alloy reduces the overpotential of HER is due to the synergistic effect between Pd and Pt, which increases the HER reaction rate. As illustrated in Fig. 7c, Wang et al. [104] outlined the creation of a bilayer Pd-Pt alloy nanocage catalyst boasting enhanced HER catalytic activity. This nanocage was fabricated by etching a Pd template comprising alternating shells of Pd and Pt, resulting in a multi-shell nano-cube with distinct (100) surfaces. The double-layer Pd-Pt nanocages, featuring sub-nanometer shells, demonstrate high dispersion of active atoms on both the inner and outer surfaces of both the outer and inner layers. Furthermore, thanks to the synergistic effect of Pd-Pt, the overpotential of HER is notably reduced, accelerating the HER reaction rate. The clever design of the double-layer nanocages presents a novel approach to enhance the atomic utilization efficiency of Pd catalysts. The structural stability of single-atom alloys is crucial for long-term activity. In the electrochemical environment of HER reaction, the catalyst needs to resist the deactivation processes such as agglomeration and dissolution. The metal interaction in the alloy structure can enhance the stability of Pd single atom. 4.3 Space limitations The modification of Pd SACs using space constraints refers to dispersing Pd atoms in the form of single atoms on the catalyst carrier, and controlling the pore size and surface structure of the carrier to limit the movement and aggregation of Pd atoms, keeping them in a single atom dispersed state [60,105]. This spatial limitation helps to enhance the performance of catalysts, thereby improving the effectiveness of water electrolysis reactions. Pd SACs are modified using spatial limitations to improve the performance of the catalyst by restricting the movement and aggregation of Pd atoms, thereby improving the effectiveness of water electrolysis reactions. Pd SACs are prone to aggregation to form clusters or solid particles, which often reduces their catalytic performance and stability. By selecting appropriate nano pore size and surface structure, the diffusion and aggregation of Pd atoms can be restricted, preventing the formation of clusters or particles, thereby maintaining a stable single atom dispersion state. This spatial limitation helps to improve the utilization of surface active sites of catalysts, increase reaction activity, and reduce the occurrence of side reactions, thereby improving the efficiency of the water electrolysis process [73,106]. In addition, spatial limitations can provide a certain protective effect, preventing adverse interactions between Pd atoms and catalyst carriers or reactants, and maintaining the stability of the catalyst. In addition, it can also avoid irreversible reactions between Pd atoms and impurities or harmful substances such as oxygen in electrolytic water, thereby extending the service life of the catalyst. Due to the fact that Pd belongs to the category of precious metal catalysts, although precious metal catalysts own extraordinary catalytic activity, there are high-cost constraints. Consequently, one of the reasons why single atom catalytic modification has attracted great attention is to explore whether it is possible to further stabilize the existence of Pd single atoms by utilizing the characteristics of spatial limitations, so as to achieve more efficient catalytic efficiency with a smaller amount of precious metal catalysts. Wang et al. [107] proposed the utilization of atomically dispersed Pd to form new PdxTaS2 compounds within layered TaS2 lattices. The atomic-level dispersion of Pd in the lattice is achieved through the following spatial constraints: Pd atoms form a new compound, Pd0.1TaS2, within the van der Waals energy gap of TaS2. In Pd0.1TaS2 shown in Fig. 7d, each Pd is surrounded by six sulfur atoms, forming a [PdS6] octahedron occupying the middle layer, indicating that Pd atoms are distributed atomically. The conductivity of metal Pd0.1TaS2 (1.36104 S m−1) is the best. As shown in Fig. 7e and f, the compound exhibits excellent catalytic performance as a novel HER electrocatalyst, with an initial overpotential of 77 mV, which comes out to be the best. Density functional theory calculations indicate that the interaction between Pd-4d and Ta-5d orbitals leads to an increase in the Fermi level (both TaS2 and Pd0.1TaS2), thereby lowering the potential barrier height of HER. In addition, the hybridization of Pd-4d and S-3p orbitals establishes a pathway along the c-axis to enhance conductivity and promote HER performance. It is worth noting that the amount of Pd0.1TaS2 is only 4 wt%, which is fantastic for its practical application and opens up new ideas for further improvement and efficient catalysis of electrolyzed water. 4.4 Surface defect engineering Defect engineering is a method of altering the catalytic performance of materials by introducing or regulating their defects. In terms of modification of Pd SACs, defect engineering has the following advantages: by introducing defects, the number of active sites and catalytic activity of Pd SACs can be increased [85,108]. These defects can provide additional reaction centers, improve catalytic activity, and promote reaction rates. Pd SACs are often prone to aggregation to form nanoparticles, thereby reducing their catalytic activity and stability. The surface defect site itself can become a new active center or cooperate with Pd single-atom to enhance the catalytic activity [49]. When defects are introduced on the surface of Pd SAC, the localization of electrons will be caused. In HER reaction, this electron localization can change the electronic structure of Pd single atom and adjust its adsorption energy for protons (H +). Because the charge density near the defect increases due to the aggregation of electrons, which affects the electrostatic interaction between Pd single atom and H + and optimizes the adsorption process [52]. Surface defects can interact directly with Pd atoms. In HER reaction, the rapid transfer and reaction of H + between defect sites and Pd atoms can accelerate the reduction process of protons, reduce the energy barrier of the reaction, and improve the activity of the catalyst [109]. By regulating the type and concentration of defects, the adsorption and dissociation rates of reactants on the catalyst surface can be increased, and the reaction rate and catalytic efficiency can be improved. Overall, defect engineering has advantages in enhancing catalytic activity, improving stability, regulating selectivity, and enhancing reaction kinetics in the modification of Pd SACs. These advantages make defect engineering an effective method to improve the catalytic performance of Pd SACs. Wazzan et al. [110] investigated the potential carbon (C18 nanoclusters) and its similar structures (B9N9 and Al9N9 nanoclusters) as carriers in the HER and OER of transition metals (TMs). They concluded that the introduction of Ni, Pd, and Pt atoms on nanoclusters reduced the difference between the highest occupied and lowest unoccupied molecular orbital energies (HOMO-LUMO gap), and achieved an improvement in carrier conductivity. Relevant literature suggests that bilayer borophenols synthesized on silver and copper possess exceptionally flat large surface areas and remarkable conductivity [111]. The van der Waals energy gap of these borophenols can be filled by metal atoms, thereby enabling the adjustment of layered boron's properties. Chang et al. [112] and colleagues introduced clamping B/TM/B (transition metal, TM=Co, Ni, Cu, Pd) as a novel 2D formate salt. By incorporating TM atoms into the bilayer borophenol, it demonstrates energy, structural, and thermal stability. Moreover, it serves as a novel platform for electrocatalytic HER. Embedding metal atoms as single atom catalysts, TM is protected by an external boron layer and is not corroded by acidic/alkaline solutions. Due to the complex d-orbital electron arrangement and numerous singular properties of transition elements in the third and fourth cycles, high-throughput calculations are needed to search for new structures [113]. As shown in Fig. 8 a, the results of B/TM/B (TM=Co, Ni, Cu, Pd) reveal their structural stability. B/Cux/B, B/Pdx/B, and B/Alx/B with different metal coverage exhibit extremely low HER free energy independent of defects, ranging from approximately −0.162 eV to 0.179 eV, −0.134 eV to 0.183 eV, and −0.082 eV to 0.086 eV. Combining excellent conductivity, high structure and thermal stability, low intercalation resistance, effortless water decomposition process, excellent non defect catalytic performance, cheap and abundant raw materials, and corrosion resistance [114]. As shown in Fig. 8b, the 2D interlayer B/Pd/B has good application performance, which undoubtedly has research prospects for electrocatalytic applications. However, if there are too many defects or the defect structure is unstable, the structure of the catalyst may collapse or the active site may be destroyed. Therefore, it is necessary to reasonably control the number and type of surface defects to ensure the long-term stability of the catalyst while improving the activity, and to ensure the continuous and efficient catalytic effect in the HER reaction process. 4.5 Design conductive substrate In the application field of electrolyzed water, a conductive substrate refers to a material with good conductivity used for catalyst modification. Pd SAC is a catalyst composed of a single Pd atom, which has high catalytic activity and selectivity [115,116]. In order to improve the electrocatalytic performance of Pd SACs, it is often necessary to modify them by loading them on conductive substrates. The selection of conductive substrates mainly considers their conductivity and compatibility with Pd catalysts [117]. Common conductive substrates include carbon materials (such as carbon nanotubes, graphene, etc.), metal oxides (such as titanium dioxide, indium tin oxide, etc.), and metal substrates (such as gold, silver, etc.). These conductive substrates can provide good electron transfer channels and promote the electrocatalytic activity of the catalyst [118]. Different conductive substrates have different electron cloud density and work function. When Pd single atom is loaded on a conductive substrate, charge transfer will occur due to the interaction between the two. The electronic orbitals of the conductive substrate and Pd atoms are coupled. The appropriate d-band center position can optimize the interaction between Pd single atom and H +, making the adsorption and reaction process easier. The conductive substrate will produce a certain surface charge distribution under the action of electric field [57]. In the electrochemical environment of HER reaction, the electric field on the surface of the conductive substrate will affect the electron distribution around the Pd single atom. The application of a certain potential will distort the electron cloud, so as to adjust the electrostatic interaction between Pd single atom and H + and promote the adsorption and reduction reaction of H + on Pd single atom [119]. Developing efficient catalysts with accelerated alkaline HER kinetics is crucial, but due to the challenging slow processes including water adsorption, how to fully utilize the characteristics of conductive substrates to improve electrolysis efficiency has become a new challenge [120]. As shown in Fig. 8c, Zhu et al. [86] used isolated Pd atoms anchored in a few layers of Ti3C2Tx MXene (Tx represents surface terminated groups) for HER under alkaline conditions. Mechanism studies have shown that doping with Pd atoms can effectively promote adsorption and dissociation caused by strong electron interactions in water [121]. Meanwhile, the downward shift of the p-band center of the O atom from the surface protonated group can optimize the adsorption of hydrogen on Pd1-Ti3C2Tx during HER. Fig. 8d-f shows a series of characterization techniques, indicating that the catalyst has Pd-O and Pd-Pd bonds, demonstrating its unique structural energy advantage. Therefore, Pd1-Ti3C2Tx exhibits enhanced performance in alkaline HER. From the polarization curve in Fig. 8g, it can be seen that Pd1-Ti3C2Tx has a higher current density and lower initial potential than Ti3C2Tx and its activity is enhanced by anchoring isolated Pd atoms. When the amount of Pd is 0.1 % to 0.5 %, the current density of Pd1-Ti3C2Tx increases with the increase of current density. Specifically, 0.5 % Pd1-Ti3C2Tx exhibits a minimum overpotential of 154 mV at 10 mA cm−2, which is much lower for Ti3C2Tx. In addition, as shown in Fig. 8h, a 0.5 % Pd1-Ti3C2Tx exhibits a lower Tafel slope of 70 mV dec−1 compared to 91 mV dec−1 of Ti3C2Tx, demonstrating that a conductive substrate with Pd atom anchoring effectively accelerates HER kinetics. 5 Modification strategies to promote catalytic activity of Pd single atom in OER In order to further improve the catalytic efficiency of OER, the modification of Pd single atom can be carried out from different angles on the principle of electronic structure coordination. Different methods are used to make Pd single atom produce electron interaction, change its electronic structure, adjust the electronic distribution of d orbital and the position of d-band center. For example, doping Ru atoms, the electronegativity of Ru is relatively large, which will make the center of the d-band of Pd close to the Fermi level, and enhance the adsorption capacity of OER intermediate products [122]. By adjusting the electronic structure of Pd single atom, the adsorption and desorption properties of OER intermediates were optimized. Appropriate changes in electronic structure can make the adsorption of OER intermediates on Pd neither strong nor weak, thus reducing the reaction energy barrier and improving OER activity. At the same time, the synergistic active sites formed by doping atoms and Pd atoms increase the number of active centers, which is conducive to OER. According to but not limited to the above modification principles, the researchers proposed the following specific measures and methods that may be achieved [40,123]. 5.1 Non-metallic atomic anchoring The synergistic enhancement of OER performance by non-metallic atoms and Pd atom is a method of fixing Pd atoms on the surface of catalysts by introducing non-metallic atoms. The performance of catalysts is improved through mechanisms such as anchoring effect, morphology control, and electronic control. This method plays an important role in improving the stability, selectivity, and catalytic activity of catalysts. The synergistic effect of non-metallic atoms can achieve lower metal loading while maintaining higher catalytic activity [124]. In summary, the synergistic effect of non-metallic atoms has advantages in the modification of Pd SACs, such as high selectivity, enhanced stability, resource conservation, and improved catalytic activity [51]. Non-metallic atom anchoring can create more favorable active sites for the OER of Pd single atom. For example, when the N atom is anchored near the Pd single atom, the electronic environment around the Pd single atom is changed, so that the adsorption energy of Pd single atom for OER intermediate products such as OH−, OOH−, etc. is optimized. It is not strong enough to make the product difficult to desorb, but weak enough to make the reaction unable to proceed effectively, so as to improve the rate of OER. The interaction between Pd single atom and OER reaction intermediates was adjusted by non-metallic atom anchoring modification. The CN stoichiometry of graphite nitride carbon (g-CN) is 1:1. As a new member of carbon nitride, g-CN has larger holes than g-C3N4 and is more likely to accommodate more active sites. Specifically, compared to g-C2 N, the higher proportion of N in g-CN may lead to stronger binding with metal atoms, which is why it has been used to explore the modification of Pd SACs. Chen et al. [92] systematically investigated a series of transition metal (TM) atoms anchored on g-CN using its porous properties (TM@CN) in HER, OER, and ORR. The OER and ORR performance were evaluated using a two-dimensional volcano map to evaluate the theoretical reaction barriers of OER and ORR. The OER and ORR performance of the candidate is divided into four regions, with red and blue indicating good activity and poor OER or ORR catalytic performance, which can be easily observed from the graph Pb@CN Showing good ORR performance with very satisfactory overpotential. As shown in Fig. 9 a and b, they used the sum of OER and ORR as the overpotential, η s=η OER+η ORR, to characterize the catalytic performance of OER/ORR bifunctional catalysts [124]. The red and blue regions represent regions with good and poor activity, respectively, which can be clearly observed Pd@CN all are located near the divided red area, indicating excellent catalytic performance. From Fig. 9c and d, it can be seen that there is a good goodness of fit between ΔG OOH* and ΔG OH*, and they have a relatively lower overpotential. It comes out that Pd@CN can serve as a promising HER/OER/ORR multifunctional catalyst, which helps to better understand the mechanism of improved catalytic activity in catalysis and explore higher quality prospective materials [77]. 5.2 Functionalised metal-organic frameworks MOF stands for Metal Organic Frameworks, which are materials with periodic structures, high adjustability, and porosity formed by coordination bonds between metal ions or metal clusters and organic ligands. MOF derivatives refer to the generation of new compounds or materials through chemical modification or transformation of MOF materials. In the application field of water electrolysis, Pd SAC is a catalyst that can promote the reaction of water electrolysis, and can be used for the electrolysis of water to produce hydrogen and oxygen [125]. MOF derivatives can serve as carrier materials and form MOF derivatives modified with Pd SACs by combining with them. MOF derived materials have rich coordination sites and unique crystal structure. In the process of MOF derived modification, the coordination environment of Pd single atom will change, forming specific coordination bonds with organic ligands or metal nodes in the material, resulting in changes in the distribution of electron cloud, which will affect the electronic structure of Pd single atom [126]. Organic ligands in MOF usually have conjugated structures, which can generate electron delocalization with Pd single atom. Electrons can be transferred and shared between the conjugated system and Pd single atom, which can adjust the electronic structure of Pd single atom, increase the delocalization degree of its d-orbital electrons, and change the center position of d-band [127]. There is an interface interaction between MOF derived support and Pd single atom. Due to their different electronic properties, the interface charge transfer will occur. If the electron cloud density of MOF derived carrier is high, the electrons will transfer to Pd single atom, on the contrary, the electrons of Pd single atom will transfer to the carrier. This charge transfer changes the electron cloud density and oxidation state of Pd single atom, so as to coordinate its electronic structure [61]. Szilágyi et al. [128] investigated the potential of fixing transition metal single atoms in a metal organic framework using a Pd model system loaded with NH2 −MIL-101 (Cr). Their transmission electron microscopy and in-situ Raman spectroscopy results have demonstrated for the first time that functionalized metal organic frameworks can support, separate, and stabilize single atoms of palladium, making it possible for Pd SACs to achieve greater stability and efficiency [129]. Therefore, single atoms loaded on metal organic frameworks may become promising single atom catalysts in the future. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are anticipated to serve as oxygen electrocatalysts owing to their flexible structures, ultra-high surface areas, porosity, and high catalytic activity [130]. Nevertheless, developing a dual-functional oxygen electrocatalyst based on MOF materials that exhibits substantial activity and durability remains a significant challenge. Zhang et al. [131] employed density functional theory (DFT) to comprehensively investigate the electronic and catalytic properties of M3 (triphenyl-2, 3, 6, 7, 10, 11-hexathiol)2 [M3(THT)2] nanosheets, incorporating nine distinct central metal atoms. Their findings indicate that the electronic and catalytic properties of the [M3(THT)2] nanosheets are predominantly influenced by the central metal atom. Wannakao et al. [132] conducted DFT calculations to explore the OER/ORR processes on metalloporphyrin and halogenated metalloporphyrin frameworks. The model employed in this study represents a 2D structure of a metalloporphyrin skeleton embedded within a 3D space, linked by benzene rings in both x and y directions, as illustrated in Fig. 9e and f, a 15 Å vacuum layer was introduced between each set of 2D sheets. The active metal sites, including M=Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn, Ru, Rh, Pd, Ag, Ir, Pt, and Au, are situated at the core of the porphyrin rings. The free energy of reaction intermediates, such as OH, O, and OOH, was determined for 14 metal sites, and Au. It was found that using Pd single atoms as substituents brought the adsorption free energy of modified cobalt porphyrin closer to the ideal point of OER/ORR, thereby reducing overpotential [133]. 5.3 Single atom alloying The single atom alloy structure can adjust the selectivity of catalysts by changing the type and proportion of metals [134]. The interaction between different metals can alter the energy of the reaction transition state, thereby affecting the selectivity of the reaction. The single atom alloying method can achieve accurate control, making the catalyst more selective. The metal surface of a single atom alloy structure can provide more adsorption sites, increasing the contact area between the catalyst and reactants [41]. This can enhance the adsorption capacity of reactants, improve the reaction rate and efficiency [11]. Overall, designing single atom alloys in Pd SACs for OER has the advantages of regulating activity, improving stability, regulating selectivity, and enhancing adsorption capacity [104]. These advantages make designing single atom alloys an effective strategy for improving catalyst performance and optimizing catalytic reactions. The design of Pd SAA catalysts not only demonstrates superior HER activity in terms of water electrolysis catalytic efficiency but also exerts significant impacts in other domains. The performance of SAA catalysts in the OER domain relies not solely on atomic interactions, but also on alterations in electronic structure and active sites [135]. Building on this, Qin et al. [99] successfully incorporated Pd atoms into Pt3Sn intermetallic compounds, aiming to bolster their acidic OER performance. Referring to Fig. 10 a, the regular structure between intermetallic compounds and the interaction between Pd and Pt atoms result in the uniform distribution of Pd atoms on the surface of Pt3Sn, thereby synthesizing Pd SAA (Pd-Pt3Sn). Fig. 10b-d depict various morphological characteristics of Pd-Pt3Sn. Notably, the Pd-Pt3Sn catalyst, as discerned from the linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) curve depicted in Fig. 10e, exhibits optimal acidic OER activity. As illustrated in Fig. 10f, achieving a current density of 10 mA cm−2 requires a potential of merely 270 mV, outperforming Pt3Sn, commercial Pd/C, and IrO2 catalysts. This underscores that the introduction of Pd atoms can notably diminish the overpotential of Pt3Sn. The incorporation of Pd suggests that alloy structures harboring Pd atoms possess additional active sites, making them more beneficial to OER under acidic conditions. Single-atom alloying changes the active site properties of Pd. Compared with pure Pd, the adsorption energy of the alloyed Pd monoatom for OER intermediates changed. The appropriate alloying atoms can make the adsorption energy of Pd single atom to the intermediate reach the optimal state, which is not only conducive to the adsorption and activation of the intermediate, but also convenient for the desorption of the product, so as to improve the OER reaction rate. 5.4 Design conductive substrate As the carrier of the catalyst, the substrate material can precisely control the carrier properties of Pd SACs by adjusting parameters such as the morphology, crystal plane structure, and pore structure of the substrate, thereby regulating the selectivity and reaction rate of catalytic reactions [136]. Design a substrate material with good conductivity and physicochemical stability, which can serve as a carrier for catalysts. Catalysts can be prepared on substrates through simple adsorption, deposition, and other methods [137,138]. At the same time, substrate materials with good conductivity can also provide a convenient way for the recovery and reuse of catalysts. In summary, designing substrate materials with good conductivity has advantages in optimizing catalytic activity, improving stability, enhancing controllability, and facilitating preparation and recovery of Pd SACs for OER reaction processes [139]. This makes improving the conductivity of the substrate material an important strategy for designing and optimizing Pd SACs [140]. Developing cost-effective bifunctional electrocatalysts is an urgent requirement for electrochemical energy applications. Guo et al. [141] examined the ORR and OER catalytic performance of individual platinum group metals (PGM) and comprehensively studied the atomically modified Janus-WSE monolayer system. The findings reveal that a single PGM atom can stably occupy the W top position on the S side, effectively modulating the structure and electronic characteristics of the Janus WSSe monolayer. As illustrated in Fig. 10g and h, Pd-WSE and Pt-WSE were identified within the PGM-WSSe system, highlighting their exceptional bifunctional catalytic activity and the free energy distribution of ORR and OER with solvation effects [121]. The Pt-WSE electrocatalyst exerts minimal influence on solvation effects and efficient dual-functional catalyst performance, whereas the low overpotential exhibited by Pd-WSE suggests its superior catalytic capabilities. Therefore, reducing the amount of PGM in PGM SACs and improving the Janus WSSe monolayer can achieve bifunctional catalytic performance, which will help promote the exploration of new bifunctional electrocatalysts [142]. 6 Conclusion and outlook 6.1 Conclusion In general, the research of Pd monoatomic catalyst in the field of electrolytic water shows a very valuable development. Based on the structural characteristics of Pd single atom, it has many advantages: high atomic utilization to achieve efficient catalysis, uniform active sites to ensure reaction consistency, and unique coordination environment to control the reaction path [143]. Therefore, based on the above structural characteristics and the principle of electronic structure coordination, different modification methods can be designed to optimize the adjustment of electron cloud density, and optimize the distribution of d-orbital electrons to enhance activity [144]. In HER reaction, when the carrier with electron donating properties is selected, the electron cloud density of Pd single atom increases, which enhances its adsorption capacity for protons and accelerates the reduction process of protons. It has been studied that Pd single atom was loaded on electron rich carbon nanotubes. In acidic electrolyte, the overpotential of HER was significantly reduced and the reaction rate was significantly improved. In the OER reaction, by accurately controlling the coordination environment of Pd single atom and optimizing its d orbital electron distribution, Pd single atom can have appropriate adsorption energy for OER intermediate products (such as OOH*, O*), thus significantly improving the catalytic activity of OER [145]. The performance can be improved through active sites and carrier synergy: in HER and OER reactions, the carrier not only plays the role of supporting Pd single atom, but also affects its activity through electron transfer and other ways [146]. For example, Pd monoatomic catalysts supported on some metal oxide supports have good catalytic activity for HER and OER in alkaline electrolyte due to the electronic interaction between the supports and Pd single-atom, which improves the overall performance of the catalysts. Stable structure ensures long-term catalytic activity: the structural stability of Pd SAC is crucial to its long-term catalytic activity [147,148]. In the practical application of electrolytic water, the stable structure can ensure that the Pd single atom does not agglomerate or lose in the long reaction process [149]. If a special preparation method is adopted to form a strong chemical bond between Pd single atom and the carrier, and the electrolytic water test is carried out in acidic and alkaline electrolyte for a long time, the activity of the catalyst decays very slowly, showing good stability [150]. Due to its unique electronic and geometric structure, Pd monoatomic catalyst can be used as multifunctional catalyst. It is widely used in HER and OER. Table 1 lists some research data on Pd SACs. 6.2 Outlook Due to the room for improvement in many aspects of Pd SACs, many studies have been conducted around the above-mentioned issues, providing various ideas for further improving the performance of Pd SACs [151]. 6.2.1 Low cost macro scale preparation Developing efficient macroscopic preparation methods represents the key to enabling the large-scale application of single-atom Pd catalysts. Currently, certain preparation techniques, including liquid-phase synthesis and atomic layer deposition, have attained success in laboratory settings. However, they necessitate further optimization and enhancement to boost preparation efficiency and cut down costs [37]. For instance, it is feasible to explore novel synthesis strategies. Techniques like pyrolysis, flame spray, and electrostatic self-assembly can be investigated to realize the macroscopic preparation of single-atom Pd catalysts. This exploration of new methods holds the potential to break through the existing bottlenecks in preparation, making the large-scale production of single-atom Pd catalysts more accessible and cost-effective, which is crucial for their widespread application in various industrial and technological fields [152,153]. 6.2.2 Interface control Advanced theoretical calculations and simulation methods allow us to deeply understand the electronic structure and catalytic reaction mechanism of single-atom Pd at various interfaces [154]. This knowledge is crucial for designing catalysts with tailored interface structures to optimize their activity and selectivity. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations, for instance, can predict vital parameters like the adsorption energy, reaction pathway, and activation energy of Pd atoms at different interfaces [155]. The activity of single-atom Pd can be regulated by constructing diverse interfaces. When forming heterogeneous interfaces with other metals or metal oxides, the electronic structure of Pd atoms is altered, influencing their adsorption capacity for reactants and intermediates [156]. Also, adjusting the carrier's surface properties, such as surface defects and functional groups, impacts the stability and catalytic activity of Pd atoms [157]. In situ characterization techniques are essential for grasping the dynamic behavior of single-atom Pd catalysts under interface regulation. In situ X-ray absorption fine structure spectroscopy (XAFS), for example, can monitor real-time changes in the coordination environment and electronic structure of Pd atoms [158,159]. 6.2.3 Chemical modification Chemical modification is a potent way to enhance the stability of single - atom Pd electrocatalysts. Introducing specific chemical groups or protective layers on the catalyst surface can prevent issues like agglomeration, oxidation, and corrosion during reactions, thus boosting stability [160]. For example, organic ligands, polymers, or inorganic oxides can be used to chemically modify single-atom Pd, forming stable coordination structures or protective layers. Controlling synthesis conditions and surface treatment methods can also adjust the catalyst's surface chemical properties and structure for enhanced stability. Modifying the surface with thiols or amines, for instance, can improve its anti-poisoning ability [161]. Selecting a high-performance carrier further improves the efficiency of Pd SACs. Loading Pd single atoms onto MXene can enhance the catalyst's stability and anti-poisoning capacity. Loading them onto high-surface-area supports like carbon nanotubes, graphene, or metal oxides increases the number of active sites and stability [47]. 6.2.4 Multi strategy coupling Introducing heteroatoms like N, S, P can modify the catalyst's electronic structure and chemical properties, enhancing catalytic performance [162]. N doping boosts conductivity and surface active sites. S doping regulates Pd atoms' electronic structure for better hydrogen adsorption. Introducing defects, such as oxygen and metal vacancies by controlling preparation, increases active sites. Combining single-atom Pd with other catalysts, like transition metal oxides or carbon materials, creates composite catalysts, leveraging their strengths to improve conductivity, stability, and catalytic activity [163]. A brief summary of the challenges currently faced by Pd single atom catalysts and potential avenues for exploration is presented in Fig. 11 . Single-atom Pd catalysts are extensively applied in electrocatalytic hydrogen production. Their unique structure enables high activity in diverse pH conditions: fast proton activation in acid and hydroxide-interference resistance in alkali. In seawater electro-hydrogen production, they resist impurities. These uses show their great potential in energy and environmental protection, promising to drive sustainable energy development in more scenarios. coredata.dc:description: In recent years, researchers have focused on developing efficient and environmentally friendly technologies to obtain clean and renewable energy, making electrolysis of water an attractive research direction. The actual performance of water splitting largely depends on the efficiency of electrocatalysts, which can promote cathodic hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) or anodic oxygen evolution reaction (OER). Reducing metal nanostructures to the atomic level to construct single atom catalysts (SACs) has attracted great attention. Compared to traditional precious metal catalysts, single atom catalysts have better catalytic activity, lower cost, and higher stability. Among many single-atom catalyst materials, palladium (Pd) single-atom materials have significant advantages in the aspects of uniform active sites, unique coordination environment, adjustable electron cloud density, and optimized d-orbital electron distribution. This review first summarizes the single-atom structure characteristics, historical development and reaction mechanism of palladium catalyzed in HER and OER. Secondly, the synthesis methods and characterization characteristics of Pd SACs are introduced. Then, the modification strategies to improve the catalytic performance of HER and OER are summarized. Finally, the possible research direction of palladium atom catalyst in the field of electrolytic water is proposed.
